verses.text: Peter and John were going up to the temple at the hour of prayer, the ninth hour.
verses.comment: Jewish tradition had set times for prayer; the 'ninth hour' is about 3 p.m. The apostles remain faithful to the rhythm of communal prayer, pointing to continuity with Israel’s worship.

verses.text: A man who was lame from birth was being carried, whom people would lay daily at the gate of the temple called 'the Beautiful Gate' to ask for alms from those entering the temple.
verses.comment: Almsgiving was a central act of piety, and placing the man at the temple gate highlights the importance of mercy and prayer.

verses.text: When he saw Peter and John about to enter the temple, he began to ask them for alms.
verses.comment: The expectation of charity at the temple frames the coming miracle as both an act of mercy and a sign of God’s power.

verses.text: Peter looked straight at him, as did John, and Peter said, 'Look at us.'
verses.comment: Direct eye contact foreshadows the personal nature of divine healing and draws a parallel to how Christ personally engaged those he healed.

verses.text: He paid attention to them, expecting to receive something from them.
verses.comment: The expectation is for material aid, but the apostles will provide something much greater—a spiritual gift.

verses.text: But Peter said, 'Silver or gold I do not have, but what I do have I give you: In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, rise up and walk.'
verses.comment: The miracle is performed by the authority of Jesus' name—a strong affirmation of Christ’s divinity and ongoing power working through his apostles. References to the name indicate sacramental power and divine authority.

verses.text: Then he took him by the right hand and raised him up, and immediately his feet and ankles were made strong.
verses.comment: Physical touch in miracles echoes how Christ healed; fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy seen in Isaiah, signaling the messianic age.

verses.text: He leaped up, stood, and began to walk; and he entered the temple with them, walking and leaping and praising God.
verses.comment: His entering the temple signifies restoration and inclusion into worshiping community. Leaping fulfills messianic prophecies in Isaiah.

verses.text: All the people saw him walking and praising God.
verses.comment: Public witness of the miracle brings attention to the work of God and opens a door for the Gospel.

verses.text: They recognized him as the one who used to sit and beg at the Beautiful Gate of the temple, and they were filled with wonder and amazement at what had happened to him.
verses.comment: The crowd’s amazement parallels the reaction to Jesus’s miracles; signs and wonders prepare hearts for deeper faith.

verses.text: While he clung to Peter and John, all the people, utterly astonished, ran together to them at Solomon's Portico.
verses.comment: Solomon’s Portico connects to Jesus’ ministry locations, symbolizing continuity as well as fulfillment.

verses.text: When Peter saw this, he addressed the people: 'Men of Israel, why are you amazed at this, or why do you stare at us, as though by our own power or godliness we had made him walk?'
verses.comment: Peter deflects personal glory, attributing the miracle to Christ's power—emphasizing humility and dependency on grace.

verses.text: 'The God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, the God of our fathers, has glorified his servant Jesus, whom you delivered up and rejected before Pilate, though Pilate had decided to release him.'
verses.comment: Christ is described as God's glorified servant, linking back to the Suffering Servant in Isaiah—fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: 'But you rejected the Holy and Righteous One and asked for a murderer to be granted to you.'
verses.comment: Titles 'Holy and Righteous One' denote divinity and sinlessness, echoing messianic prophecies.

verses.text: 'And you killed the Author of life, whom God raised from the dead. We are witnesses to this.'
verses.comment: 'Author of life' links to high christology—Jesus as the source and sustainer of life. The resurrection is central, and their witness makes apostles spiritual authorities.

verses.text: 'And by faith in his name, this man whom you see and know was made strong; and the faith that comes through Jesus has given him perfect health in the presence of you all.'
verses.comment: Salvation and healing come through faith in Christ’s name, indicative of sacramental efficacy and spiritual transformation.

verses.text: 'Now, brothers, I know that you acted in ignorance, as did your rulers.'
verses.comment: Peter expresses mercy, paralleling Jesus’ prayer on the cross—pointing toward forgiveness and the possibility of reconciliation.

verses.text: 'But what God foretold by the mouth of all the prophets, that his Christ would suffer, he has fulfilled in this way.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ suffering fulfills numerous prophecies. God’s plan works through history, confirming unity of Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: 'Repent therefore, and turn back, so that your sins may be wiped away,'
verses.comment: The necessity of repentance ties with Old Testament calls to conversion and forgiveness. The wiping away of sin connects with sacramental grace.

verses.text: 'so that times of refreshing may come from the presence of the Lord, and that he may send the Christ appointed for you, Jesus,'
verses.comment: Messianic language alludes to renewal and the promise of restoration—refreshment is both spiritual and eschatological.

verses.text: 'whom heaven must receive until the time for restoring all things, which God spoke about by the mouth of his holy prophets of old.'
verses.comment: References the Second Coming and restoration— Jesus remains in heaven, continuing his priestly office.

verses.text: 'Moses said, "The Lord God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your brothers. You shall listen to him in everything he tells you."'
verses.comment: Peter directly connects Jesus to the promised prophet, affirming the continuity of God’s covenant and the New Covenant’s fulfillment.

verses.text: 'And it shall be that every soul who does not listen to that prophet shall be utterly destroyed from among the people.'
verses.comment: Eternal consequences for rejecting Christ—demonstrates the necessity of heeding divine revelation.

verses.text: 'And all the prophets who have spoken, from Samuel and those who came after him, also proclaimed these days.'
verses.comment: Peter affirms prophetic continuity. The church stands as a fulfillment of the prophetic tradition inherited from Israel.

verses.text: 'You are the sons of the prophets and of the covenant which God made with your fathers, saying to Abraham, "And in your offspring shall all the families of the earth be blessed."'
verses.comment: Emphasizes the universality of salvation—fulfillment of covenantal promise. The faith continues to bring blessing to all nations through Christ.

verses.text: 'God, having raised up his servant, sent him to bless you by turning every one of you from your wickedness.'
verses.comment: Christ’s mission is not simply forgiveness, but also moral transformation. Apostolic proclamation continues this ministry, through which the blessing and conversion of souls are extended across generations.
